name: christopher-and-tatjana

text: _@christopher.puchta has joined the channel_
_@wonderlandcrows has joined the channel_

Hey Tatjana, please meet Christopher your incredible E-Mentor I've been telling you about :smile:.  Feel free to introduce yourselves, say a little bit about what you would like to get out of the mentorship and continue chatting within this channel. :wave:

I will now be leaving the channel, but please direct message myself or emma-prospela if you have any questions. All the best for now! :slightly_smiling_face:
_@dexter has left the channel_
_@dexter has left the channel_

Morning Tatjana! Good to meet you! :slightly_smiling_face:  You're actually my first mentee in here so i'm jumping in the deep end - although i've always done this sorta thing unofficially with colleagues; giving advice etc. So i hope i'll have something useful to offer in terms of industry insights or any help you're looking for! :slightly_smiling_face:
Let me know if there's anything you had in mind you wanted help with or chat about... :thumbsup:

Hi! I'm sorry I'm answering so late :sweat_smile:
Well you're my first mentor! Maybe we'll help each other haha 

I'm more of a character design/concept artist person but there wasn't any mentor for that, I was studying 2D animation which I know Framestore does! I'm sorry if you have to go out of your way to help me because it's not your area of expertise.

I'd love to know how to approach companies and what they look for in demo reels (I'm currently working on mine).

I have to preface this by, this Sunday I learned that my school went bankrupt so I unfortunately don't have a diploma because we couldn't study there anymore. I know not everyone in the industry has diploma in their fields but it does help to have one... However, since I'm a beginner,  if it does stop me from being employable, I'll still take all of your advices, I just won't be able to act on them yet.

Anyways! If you have any questions about me don't hesitate,  and do you like your current work environment :0?

No worries about the "late" reply! Yeah i was wondering about the linking-up of mentors&mentees as well, but apparently since they're just getting started over here there's only a small pool of people available. But i'll definitely do what i can to advice, help, possibly connect you with industry resources etc to get you the most out of this as possible! :slightly_smiling_face:

I'd agree with you on the diploma-side. The more artistic it gets - i think at least - the less you actually need an official degree, but instead everybody is just looking at your artistic talent. Perfect example...i don't have a degree and no one ever asked me for it either :smile: . It can certainly be a smaller issue when immigrating for work into a different region, but with growing work experience that's definitely less of an issue

For a (first) showreel i'd go for short, concise one that shows all your best stuff and only that to start of with - instead of padding it out to reach some arbitrary length that wouldn't show your best work if that makes sense. Let me know if you want me to look at any of your designs etc, showreel ideas...
I don't know if you're from Canada and/or but there tons of companies now in the bigger cities like Vancouver/Montreal/Toronto that need char design/concept work so i'd hope (and actually am pretty sure) there would be a good amount of opportunities for you to apply for some sort of entry level position and then go from there :thumbsup:
Some companies (like Framestore where i am for example) also offer special programs to start young students off in entry positions, pair them up with a mentor to get them working on a project (or most likely even a real project we're actually working on) with a chance to keep them around for a more permanent position after that intern/mentorship period

I think nowadays, that's how the majority of people find their way into the industry...studying or self-learning to the point of actually producing some cool stuff and deciding you wanna go in that direction professionally and then starting in entry level positions and through connections you make over time work your way up :slightly_smiling_face:
It was the same for me pretty much...i studied two different things, but was quickly demotivated by the abundance of theory they had us learn...so i went off, did some things on my own, joined a few people at uni that worked on projects on the side and then decided - "maybe that's something i can actually do without finishing this study thing", applied for a freelance job that needed some specific fx-work that went pretty well, and then through a few internships at a smaller company, working my way through the industry and around the world and there's still nothing really that i'd rather do. So it didn't go too bad in the end :wink:

At the moment it's pretty quiet for us here...we're doing fx for a Netflix show but it's still early days, not a lot of people on the show so for now it's easy living :wink: ...which is actually good for this mentoring thing, since i should have more time for it during the day!

That was quite the brain dump so far :smile:...and i feel like it's probably a bit vague(?) maybe, but i wanted to get things written down that came to mind right now. Let me know if i missed anything or what you need some more insights on
Sorry to hear about your school closing btw...that sucks. Is there a chance - if you wanted to go for it - to transfer any progress to another school and finish there!?
